sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1:
Consider the metric on 3-dimensional space given by 
$$ds^2 = 3(dx^2 + dy^2) + 7 dz^2.$$ 
Find the volume form of this metric.
message_2:
To find the volume form of the given metric, we first need to write down the metric tensor. The metric tensor is a symmetric matrix that can be obtained from the given metric. In this case, the metric tensor is:

$$
g = \begin{pmatrix}
3 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 7
\end{pmatrix}
$$

The volume form is given by the square root of the determinant of the metric tensor multiplied by the standard volume form in 3-dimensional Euclidean space, which is $dV = dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$. The determinant of the metric tensor is:

$$
\det(g) = \det\begin{pmatrix}
3 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 7
\end{pmatrix} = 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 7 = 63
$$

So, the volume form is:

$$
dV = \sqrt{\det(g)} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = \sqrt{63} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz
$$
